question.title: What is the intended usage of hypersistence-utils JsonBinaryType
question.body:
Suppose I have the following table definition in postgres

create table foo_entity
(
    id                varchar(255) not null primary key,
    jsonb_column      jsonb
);

I am trying to modify the table using a native query via entity manager like so

EntityManager em; // its obtained somehow
List<String> strings = List.of("foo", "bar");
Query q = em.createNativeQuery("update foo_entity set jsonb_colimn = :value");
q.setParameter("value", new TypedParameterValue<>(
   new JsonBinaryType(new ObjectMapper()),
   strings
));
q.executeUpdate();

But I am getting an error that the provided value was of type bytea rather than the intended jsonb.

2025-07-30T13:53:09.547+03:00 DEBUG 13275 --- [demo1] [           main] o.h.engine.jdbc.spi.SqlExceptionHelper   : JDBC exception executing SQL [        update foo_entity set jsonb_column = ?
] [n/a]

org.postgresql.util.PSQLException: ERROR: column "jsonb_column" is of type jsonb but expression is of type bytea
  Hint: You will need to rewrite or cast the expression.
  Position: 46

Meanwhile if I provide a string scalar into the value, rather than an array type I get a different error

2025-07-30T13:54:57.683+03:00 DEBUG 13526 --- [demo1] [           main] o.h.engine.jdbc.spi.SqlExceptionHelper   : JDBC exception executing SQL [        update foo_entity set jsonb_column = ?
] [n/a]

org.postgresql.util.PSQLException: ERROR: column "jsonb_column" is of type jsonb but expression is of type character varying
  Hint: You will need to rewrite or cast the expression.
  Position: 46

How do I ensure that the resulting value is properly written as jsonb type?

At the time of writing i'm using Hibernate 6.6 and Hypersistence-utils 63 3.10.1

answers.body:
It seems that when you're using JsonBinaryType you must provide a non Object.class argument via JsonBinaryType(java.lang.reflect.Type) constructor, otherwise when binding parameters hibernate gets confused and attempts to guess the parameter type rather than using value's class as seen by following lines 87-104 in AbstractJdbcParameter.java

    private JdbcMapping jdbcMapping(ExecutionContext executionContext, JdbcParameterBinding binding) {
        JdbcMapping jdbcMapping = binding.getBindType();

        if ( jdbcMapping == null ) {
            jdbcMapping = this.jdbcMapping;
        }

        // If the parameter type is not known from the context i.e. null or Object, infer it from the bind value
        if ( jdbcMapping == null || jdbcMapping.getMappedJavaType().getJavaTypeClass() == Object.class ) { // <- always true in default case
            jdbcMapping = guessBindType( executionContext, binding.getBindValue(), jdbcMapping );
        }

        if ( jdbcMapping == null ) {
            throw new ExecutionException( "No JDBC mapping could be inferred for parameter - " + this );
        }

        return jdbcMapping;
    }

Since getMappedJavaType() returns Object.class (which is the default), hibernate will attempt to guess the binder that should be used, rather than explicitly use the one provided by JsonBinaryType, which will end up being being something like SerializableJavaType or StringJavaType, as well as write the wrong sqlTypeCode (17 for bytea, instead of expected 3802 for jsonb).

question_comments.body: @LaurenzAlbe apparently hibernate was really confused and thought it was writing a bytea type all along rather than the expected type. Providing extra metadata tweaks the resulting type and prevents the issue.

@LaurenzAlbe that does work if I wrap it with to_jsonb function rather than casting because hibernate seems to pass bytea/varchar argument, but i'd expect it to be handled for me, hence the usage of hypersistence-utils package that vlad provides.

Binding a JSON as binary type is clearly wrong. For other data types where Hibernate doesn't get the data type right, an explicit cast would help: update foo_entity set jsonb_colimn = CAST (:value AS jsonb).
This question is explicitly about native queries, and not about entities. Do not suggest answers or related questions that wrap the table with respective entity.
